summary: Mel Gibson portrays Benjamin Martin, an unassuming man who is forced to join the American Revolution when the British threaten to take his farm away from him. Together with his patriotic son, Gabriel, the pair faces the vicious Redcoats with a heroism that reflects the stubborn pride of a young country's most dedicated supporters.

Very confused by negative reviews of this movie. It may not be historically accurate, so if that bothers you - ok! It is occasionally unrealistic (the final battle seems to be largely won by running up a hill and waving a flag). But really - who cares? It is gloriously, beautifully cinematic, with a superb script. The cinematography is simply stunning - and the planning that went into some of the shots (as a filmmaker myself) I almost can't fathom. The story manipulates your emotions with incredible sophistication - I DARE you not to care about the family caught in the middle of this civil war, or to not want the villains defeated or dead. Mel Gibson is superbly nuanced in this movie, and on far more familiar ground than the forced Braveheart.   Heath Ledger winsomely plays his son, and Jason Isaac and Tom Wilkinson provide an indulgence of British villainy (just one of these would have carried the movie - two is a embarrassment of riches). There is room for humor, for touching moments. It's long, but earns its length. But best of all are the exhilirating and tense action pieces - in the end this IS an action movie, not a drama. Guerilla warfare is always fun to watch - and I've actually been using this movie to teach students about the recent Russian Ukraine conflict - as there are comparisons. No, leave your history books and prejudices against Gibson at the door - this is a storytelling and cinematic masterpiece, and it is really hard to think of a better war movie in the same vein. Thinking. Last Samurai comes close - but it's not really fully a war movie. Saving Private Ryan is more real, but far less charming. Robin Hood Prince of Thieves? Great Escape? Inglorious Bastards? No. Fail. Because, in fact, many of the contenders are not really war movies - or not entirely. This is. The war is the whole shebang. There is no better war movie. Prove me wrong.

When it comes to badly done historical films, Mel Gibson has the rights. Hollywood's attempts to rewrite history are most obvious to history buffs like myself. The film begins in 1776 just before the signing of the Declaration. An uneasy time. Tensions are high. They think about breaking away from the British Empire and establishing their own nation. But contrary to popular belief today. Not everyone wanted independence at that point in time. America was not United. Many consider it to be a civil war. The "Tories" (loyalists) consider the British to be legitimate government troops.. many loyalists joined the British army out of patriotism. And many of the native American Indian tribes sided with the British. And in 1776 only about 1/3 of America's population  support independence. The 'patriot' completely ignore all this. The only loyalist in the film is made out to be a Judas. Who is terrible. Taxation without representation was important and a just cause, obviously. But this film bearly cares about the reason behind this. Britain backed down again and again on taxing the colonists. Until they didn't. With the tax on tea. But the colonists were having none of it. There are so many other inaccuracies I could name, such as the film contradicting real life events like the British making a deal with the natives to secure them their own land with the Royal proclamation line of 1763. Hence the reason the Indians always sided with the Brits. This is contradicted in the film by having the two villains scheme about Ohio. Western expansion was inevitable, yes.. but this early on? The colonists had no representation in parliament or opportunity to move westward and so revolution escalated into war. 

2.Slaves
The character Benjamin Martin is probably based of several historical figures in late British America. But the most relevant is Francis Marion of South Carolina. His militia where brutally effective against the Brits using gorilla warfare tactics. But he was not married until after the war. That doesnt bother me much. It's the fact that Ben Martin has "free men" working on his land. That's disgusting. Offensive even. Francis Marion was a slave owner! Funnily enough. His slaves escaped from his plantation to fight for the British. 
I dont look upon past events with my modern morals but this is just offensive. 
They make out the British to be using slaves as tools of war. But the Americans do the same thing in the very next scene. But they use a different tone. The fact is when the British declared they would free any slave and pay those who served in the British military, it scared the American 'Patriots'. So when they did the same thing, they did it out of necessity not because they wanted too.

The whole film can be summed up in what Gen. Cornwallis said "These rustics are so ineptable. Nearly takes the honour out of victory. Nearly." 

Now, in war, every side commits atrocities. The British included. But this film just makes stuff up that never happened.  To the point where they depict them burning down a church filled with innocent men, women and children. Shooting injured POWs. They never did this. Its fiction. In the Boston massacre only 5 or 6 people died. Thats the most massively non- massacre massacre I've ever heard of. This type of thing is what the nazis did. Like in June 10th 1944. In a village in France a similar church burning happened which was committed by the SS.
This film is so over the top. The main character stabs Tavington's horse with the American flag. I laughed at that I must admit. Nice symbolism. 

All I suggest is you should have a film be based on real history. Instead of BS. 
There is one final thing I think I should address about this picture. Its not nearly as offensive as its depiction of slavery or fake atrocities. But its worth thinking about. The film is meant to champion the best about the U.S. The problem is the ideas it brings up are modern.. not those which actually existed back then. 
Most of the African Americans that fought for the freedom of the U.S never got their freedom. Native American Indians where killed for supporting the British or pushed out of their native land And 100,000 American Tories (loyalists) where expelled from their country of birth or where persecuted, tarred and feathered because of their loyalty to the crown. The one slave in the film gets his freedom (even though he wouldn't have in real life unless he had fought for the British) but he gets it. And what does he want to do with it? He wants to help Ben Martin build his house! Good God. What a slap in the face.

This film came out around the same time as star Mel Gibson's "Braveheart" and I remember people thinking he'd directed this film as well, particularly because of savage battle scenes. However, "The Patriot" was directed by Roland Emmerich, the reliable producer/writer/director of many enjoyable but empty headed summer popcorn films, including "Independence Day," "White House Down," and "Stargate." While most of his films are unchallenging crowd pleasers, "The Patriot" stands apart in his filmography as quality piece of filmmaking. The film was written by Robert Rodat, who also wrote "Saving Private Ryan," and he brings the same mix of realism and and emotion to the American Revolutionary War that he brought to WWII. Mel Gibson plays a farmer and retired war hero who wants nothing more than to left alone with his family and to run his farm. However, Gibson is pushed to his limits by Jason Isaacs, best known as the sneering Lucius Malfoy in the Harry Potter films, who play as a sneering British Colonel. Gibson's fictional Benjamin Martin is an amalgam of several Revolutionary War heroes, but primarily seems to be based upon Francis Marion, The Swamp Fox, who was a pivotal figure during the war, leading a group of irregular soldiers in a guerrilla war against the British in South Carolina, even after the Continental Army had been driven out the state. After Gibson's son, Heath Ledger, is captured by Issacs, Gibson leads his own ragtag band of soldiers against the redcoats using what was at the time was very unusual guerrilla tactics. The small and large scale action sequences in "The Patriot" are the real highlight of the film. They are exciting, brutally realistic, and most importantly, are emotionally poignant. There is an early scene in the film when Gibson ambushes a British detail to free his captured son, Ledger, where he uses his very young sons as his soldiers, and the filmmakers don't shy away from the young children's shock at their father telling them how to kill men, as well as taking time to show the aftermath and their reaction to their father's brutality. Besides being and exciting and unflinching in it's graphic and realistic presentation of war, it's the emotional component that elevates "The Patriot" from simply being a technically effective crafted battle sequence. However, although the film does a fine job of presenting a realistic depiction of war for this time period and also does an excellent job of period detail in terms of costumes, architecture, and set decor, the film grossly fails in it's whitewashing of history in an attempt to present a politically correct hero who's more palatable to audiences.. As I said before, "The Patriot" is a work of fiction, but having Gibson's Martin "paying" his black farmworkers instead of owning slaves seems wildly disingenuous (Francis Marion owned slaves). Additionally, the real-life Francis Marion committed many war atrocities, even by the standards of his time, which are completely absent in this film, although there are hints of something in Gibson's past during the French and Indian War. If "The Patriot" had been as honest in it's depiction of history in these respects as it had been in it's depiction of warfare, this film may have been a true classic. Despite this major lapse, "The Patriot" remains a strong piece of filmmaking, with an emotional center that focuses around family, which gives the film a resonance that is lacking from many war films. Well worth watching despite it's flaws.

Teaming up a powerful actor like Mel Gibson with a spectacle filmmaker like Roland Emmerich, The Patriot sounded like an entertaining epic.

It's a no-brainer that Roland Emmerich is not the greatest storyteller in the world as his films rely more frequently on expensive production values to captivate the audience. The Patriot is of course no exception, although its nature as a civil war film means that there isn't any room for visual effects. The film has to be constructed out of practical elements, and with Roland Emmerich as the director it succeeds at that very gracefully.
The Patriot isn't meant to be any kind of intellectually stimulating, it is clearly intended to be marketed as a blockbuster, making use of familiar elements to draw fans of existing themes in. This means that the film relies on a pre-established formula as the basis of its narrative, and it manages to integrate in predictable plot points from many genres to form a singular story. While loosely working as a historical war epic, The Patriot progressively draws in story elements particularly familiar of the action genre, pushing the film to focus more on its action than its story. Since the action is part of the spectacle in the film it manages to work, but it simply means that The Patriot ends up following a meandering path. But then again, that is to be expected from the beginning.  But since it stays on this path for a running time of nearly three hours and takes a lot of slow breaths between the action scenes where these formulaic plot points unfold, it is certainly a bit of a stretch.
In all essence the film is not bereft of death because amid its overly familiar themes are an effective reminder of just what kind of unexpected challenges one must face in war and there is tenacious acting to bring the material to life. Nevertheless, the film is an exercise in style above all else. And of course, it is a powerful one. Starting with powerful scenery and building up from there, The Patriot is packed with decorations all the way to the brim with rich costumes and production design. All this is captured with brilliant cinematography which effectively finds the correct balance between capturing the epic spectacle of the scenery and also working to find the detail in the facial expressions of the actors by zeroing in on them. But all the production values of the film come to an endeavour when the film actually enters war territory and becomes a spectacle of combat. Roland Emmerich has proven countless times just how well he can put together an effective action scene, and The Patriot features some of his most beautiful work. Instead of relying strictly on effects this time, Roland Emmerich manages to find a balance for his sense of style and some impressive choreography. The Patriot is packed with predominantly two kinds of action scenes: shootouts and close combat. The shootouts are impressively staged down to the finest detail, and yet the close combat scenes manage to transcend them even further. Both make a strong use of blood and slow motion while showing a large scope of battle going on, but the close combat also relies on extensive choreography work which the actors take on as a challenge and manage to completely blitz. The Patriot manages to fill its long running time with a sufficient quantity of action scenes between the periods of drama, and it certainly manages to fill the generic contract and create a spectacle of both genuinely great imagery and brilliant action. 
One of the finest technical assets from The Patriot is the musical score. The composer is one who is so iconic that he could be recognized by the deaf, a man responsible for creating many of the most iconic film scores of all time. The name be John Williams, and his work on The Patriot is truly stunning. With dedication to capturing the epic scope of the narrative and bringing the emotional atmosphere of the material to prominence, John Williams turns The Patrior into a treat for the ears in the same way Roland Emmerich does it for the eyes. John Williams proves once more that he never fails to create poetry with his music.
And though the script does take the audience through familiar territory, the cast in The Patriot all deliver extremely firm performances.
Mel Gibson is the standout. Having proven that he can lead an epic spectacle to the tune of the Academy Award winning Braveheart (1995), The Patriot is essentially routine for him. However, his performance clearly is not. The man knows what scale the film is going for and has no problem living up to it because he dedicates all his energy to the every theme in the film. When he has to go into speaking for extensive periods of time about his passion for his country, his patriotism rings true brilliantly enough to live up to the title of the film. When he is sent into war, he maintains an intense stare and grip over his weapon which turns into the swift movements of a trained warrior. And when the material really breaks into the heart of the character Benjamin Martin, Mel Gibson has no problem expressing the vulnerabilities of the character by really bringing himself to tears and showing a physical state of absolute emotion. Mel Gibson powerfully captures both the raw side of his character and the sophisticated demeanour while letting his natural charm overtake the part during the less melodramatic scenes, so the man proves a likable and gripping star while also delivering the goods during the action scenes.
Heath Ledger also delivers a brilliant effort. Being an accomplished Australian actor like Mel Gibson, the fact that he comes from the next generation makes the father and son sentiment of The Patriot seem all the more legitimate. And you can see elements of a young Mel Gibson's talent in Heath Ledger due to his natural charm and youthful innocence as well as his determination to take a stand. Heath Ledger provides a likable presence the entire time but also engages with Mel Gibson on the same level as him, creating chemistry so organic that the drama just flows through the film whenever he is on the screen. Heath Ledger is perfectly dramatic yet always appropriately restrained in The Patriot, proving the extent of his talents in a big-budget film.
Chris Cooper also delivers a strong supporting effort, and Adam Baldwin is a welcome face to see.

So The Patriot is a predictable film due to its reliance on a pre-existing formula of cliches over the course of its long story, but with Mel Gibson's tenacious leading performance and Roland Emmerich's keen eye for brilliant imagery,  it doesn't fail to entertain.

For example, one of the most widely known events of the British doing harm against the colonists is the Boston Massacre.  The British troops were instructed to maintain civil order within the colonies.  When colonists rioted and provoked the British soldiers, they opened fired and five were killed. During the American Revolution in 1776, Benjamin Martin (Mel Gibson), a veteran of the French and Indian War and widower with seven children, is called to Charleston to vote in the South Carolina General Assembly on a levy supporting the Continental Army. Fearing war against Great Britain, Benjamin abstains. Captain James Wilkins votes against and joins the Loyalists. A supporting vote is nonetheless passed and against his father's wishes, Benjamin's eldest son Gabriel (Heath Ledger) joins the Continental Army.Four years later in 1780, Charleston falls to the British and a wounded Gabriel returns home carrying dispatches. The Martins care for both British and American wounded from the nearby battle, before British Dragoons, led by the ruthless Colonel William Tavington (Jason Isaacs), arrive and arrest Gabriel. When Benjamin's young son Thomas tries to free Gabriel, he is shot and killed by Tavington, who orders the Martins' house burned and wounded Americans executed. After the British leave, Benjamin gives his next two eldest sons muskets and they ambush the British unit escorting a tied Gabriel. Benjamin skillfully, yet brutally, kills many soldiers with his tomahawk. A British survivor tells Tavington of the attack, earning Benjamin the moniker of the "Ghost". Benjamin quickly finds himself torn between protecting his family, and seeking revenge along with being a part of the birth of a new, young, and ambitious nation...

Widower "Benjamin Martin" (Mel Gibson), a veteran of the French/Indian War, wants only one thing -- to raise his family on the family plantation. He is totally against the brewing conflict with the British, and is at odds with his eldest son "Gabriel" (Heath Ledger), who is for going to war with Britain. The rift between the two over the war spreads more when "Gabriel" joins the militia when the state representatives, one of which is his father, votes to enter the war. However, "Benjamin" was one of the 12 to vote against entering the war. 

Then, after a battle just yards away from the Martin Plantation, "Benjamin," his other children and the slaves on the plantation are taking care of injured from both sides of that battle when a group of Redcoats come up to the plantation to take their wounded to get better medical help, and kills the revolutionists. And when "Gabriel," who returned to the plantation the night before seriously injured, is discovered with communications and is taken into custody. One of "Gabriel's" younger brothers tries to interfere, and is shot in the back and dies in his father's arms. "Benjamin," with his two youngest sons, go looking for the troops responsible for killing his son and torching his property. 

Now, "Benjamin" has revenge in his heart and realizes that "Gabriel" was right about breaking away from the British crown. 

The first thing you can't help but notice is the very accurate architecture, furnishings, weaponry and wardrobe. The producers used the Smithsonian Institute as a consultant in just about everything for accuracy. This really sets the setting of the movie quite nicely. 

Another thing that stands out is the performances. I don't think one actor gave a weak performance. Even the supporting cast, many of which had characters who weren't strongly developed past their reasons for joining "Benjamin," give good performances. 

Because it's set in the Revolutionary War, there are battle scenes with graphic blood. The battles are nicely shot, especially when the camera is surrounded by the action at ground level. There is tons of action going on in these battle scenes, with lots of explosions. 

The special effects are mainly blood packs, pyrotechnics, sounds of explosions and it looks like there is some CGI of the ocean with boats floating in it. The special effects are very effective in many scenes. 

The cinematography is done nicely, even when the scenery is rather cramped. It is pretty hard to believe that the person responsible for finding locations for the film found any place where there was no modernization, but they did. 

The phenomenal John Williams put together some good music for this movie. He was able to nail the emotion of the scenes rather nicely, as usual.
